conclusion: Determine the radius d of the light-blocking plate such that no light exits from the inner surface of the hemispherical shell.
The outer radius of the hemisphere is R' = sqrt(2)R.
The inner radius of the hemisphere is R.
The refractive index of the glass is n = sqrt(2).
For TIR to occur at the inner surface, the angle of incidence at the inner surface must be greater than or equal to the critical angle theta_c.
The critical angle theta_c is given by sin theta_c = 1/n = 1/sqrt(2) = sqrt(2)/2, therefore, theta_c = 45 degrees.
Consider a light ray incident parallel to the central axis OO' at a distance x from the axis.
This ray will strike the outer surface at a point where the radial distance from the center is sqrt(2)R.
The angle of incidence at the outer surface is theta_i, which can be found using the geometry of the hemisphere.
The angle theta_i is related to the distance x by sin theta_i = x/sqrt(2)R.
Using Snell's law, the angle of refraction theta_r inside the glass is n sin theta_i = sin theta_r, implying sin theta_r = x/R.
For TIR to occur at the inner surface, the angle of incidence at the inner surface must be >= 45 degrees, therefore, sin theta_r >= sin 45 degrees implies x/R >= sqrt(2)/2.
Solving for x gives x >= sqrt(2)/2 R.
The maximum value of x for which TIR occurs is sqrt(2)/2 R, therefore, the radius d of the light-blocking plate must be d = sqrt(2)/2 R.
The radius d of the light-blocking plate is boxed{sqrt(2)/2 R}.
